quotable_quotes.quote: Observation doesn't lead to knowledge - that there must be a theoretical framework within which is it is interpreted.
quotable_quotes.context: First of three key learnings from course - epistemological insight
quotable_quotes.significance: Challenges positivist assumption that raw observation yields knowledge; identifies framework dependency

quotable_quotes.quote: it is more important to know and do than to know
quotable_quotes.context: Second learning - emphasis on praxis over theory
quotable_quotes.significance: Values action-oriented knowledge; rejects pure contemplation

quotable_quotes.quote: Data aggregated leads to information, information aggregated leads to knowledge, knowledge aggregated leads to wisdom.
quotable_quotes.context: Describes Western linear knowledge model that user was raised in
quotable_quotes.significance: Captures the mechanistic knowledge progression model being critiqued

quotable_quotes.quote: I, as an individual, can pierce the darkness and understand God and know how to live.
quotable_quotes.context: Describing spiritual domain blindspot in Western individualism
quotable_quotes.significance: Shows recognition of spiritual arrogance in secular framework

quotable_quotes.quote: these things - as data points - are being interpreted through a framework I had no idea that I had
quotable_quotes.context: Analyzing inherited Western bias in interpreting evidence
quotable_quotes.significance: Metacognitive awareness of invisible framework shaping perception

quotable_quotes.quote: We see how Islam spread through the quality of the character, and I'm certain during it's apex the perspective of people realizing that goodness must come from goodness.
quotable_quotes.context: Contrasting Islamic civilization with Western material metrics
quotable_quotes.significance: Values character and virtue as civilization's foundation

quotable_quotes.quote: Seeing through the frameworks to interpret data and build knowledge by reflection makes me more aware of the need to know my frameworks, and to select one's that have beautiful consequences historically and are fixed firmly to unchanging truths
quotable_quotes.context: Synthesis - choosing frameworks with historical virtue and religious grounding
quotable_quotes.significance: Proposes criterion: frameworks should have beautiful historical consequences and align with religious truth

quotable_quotes.quote: which might be likened to taking a drug (oil, exponential capitalism, etc) where for a few years (200) there might be a superficiality of Goodness - built on slave labor, and other exploitable or purchasable souls - and then the crash when the costs of the corruption they've sown is mirrored from their hearts to the earth.
quotable_quotes.context: Extended metaphor for Western civilization's trajectory
quotable_quotes.significance: Powerful image of civilization as addiction with hidden costs; moral law reflected in natural consequences
